title: Why QFT?
text:
In my previous post I mentioned my interest in constructive QFT, gauge Theory and HoTT. I’ll try to explain why I’m interested in them!
When I studied logic the first time I was really fascinated by predicate logic and formal proofs. In fact, I really enjoyed solving proof problems because it followed more logically than cookie-cutter “find the missing trick” problem. I had a fascination with abstract concepts from high school at age 15.
This fascination always led me towards more abstract ideas and mathematics and along with my interest in physics. Through some chaotic explorations of Wikipedia and arXiv, I read that standard perturbative-QFT although makes predictions of scattering amplitudes extremely accurately, as a formal framework it is a bit “shaky”.
Path integrals are not well-defined measures, as it lacks rigorous \(\sigma\)-algebra and has UV-divergences. Renormalisation isn’t rigorously well understood and through RG flows QFT is better treated as an effective field theory (Richard Feynman and Paul Dirac, the pioneers of QFT famously called it “hocus pocus”, that it’s just a trick which physicists use to sweep infinities under the rug and call it a day).
Understanding why the methods of QFT work is extremely important for QFT in curved space, and to avoid using the rules in wrong situations and get fake solutions, especially in non-perturbative regimes.
This led me to discover 70-80s work of Glimm-Jaffe on constructive quantum field theory which aimed to formally justify the heuristics physicists use. They were successful in proving a mass gap in Quantum Yang-Mills Theory in two and three dimensions but hit a wall in four dimensions, which is a Millennium prize problem and extremely difficult.
In the modern era, this problem is often approached from a stochastic perspective by using Langevin dynamics in SPDEs. Martin Hairer made a breakthrough with regularity structures for singular SPDEs, for this he won many awards including the Fields medal. However, the 4D Yang-Mills still remains an open problem because of how extremely difficult it is.
I’ll explained about QFT with more technical details here.
The necessary background needed for this field (as far as im aware) is rigorous understanding of functional analysis, operator algebras, distribution theory, and measure theory. Currently my background is only basic understanding of analysis and algebra so I’m quite far from understanding the mathematics, but I’m making progress day by day at my pace.
This problem is one of the hardest in mathematical physics and people are generally cautious of young students chasing the big problems just because of the glamour. If I said that the glamour of solving big problems is not one of the reasons for chasing it, I’d probably be lying to myself. However I believe that my main reason for chasing it isn’t just for the fame or glamour, but a genuine philosophical motivation for rigour in theory.
So, this is why i want to explore more about this field and related fields such as axiomatic QFT, algebraic QFT and topological QFT, all attempting to make qft more mathematically rigorous. These are extremely sophisticated fields and typically people only work in a few in their lifetimes.
However, I haven’t decided to devote myself to this field right away, i’m in the early stage of developing my research interests so i think looking through them from a bird’s eye view would be helpful.
I’ll be talking about my other interests in future blog posts.
Servus!!

title: Hello!
text:
Continuing the discussion of QFT, i recently developed deeper interests into Algebraic Quantum Field Theory (AQFT). It is a non-perturbative formalisation of QFT that axiomatizes the assignment of algebras of observables to patches of parameter space (spacetime, worldvolume). It’s roughly the “Heisenberg picture” of quantum mechanics used in introductory textbooks.
One of the main selling points of AQFT is locality, which is essentially a way to enforce that signals cannot travel faster than light, hence preventing superluminal signaling. This is why it is sometimes also called as “local quantum physics”.
Another plus point of AQFT is that some extensions of AQFT has provided several rigorous results concerning QFT in presence of a black hole, hence it’s one of the approaches to QFT in curved spacetime as well.
A modern formalism is perturbative AQFT, which sounds ridiculous because it’s completely opposite of the objective of AQFT, but the idea of pAQFT is that since traditional AQFT has failed to produce any rigorous interacting QFT model, we try to do perturbative approximations in order to reach non-perturbative solutions.
One of the key figures in pAQFT who wrote a book in 2017 is Katarzyna Rejzner, I am still exploring her work and frankly it’s way beyond me.
A higher categorical formalism which is very similar but rooted in the Atiyah-Segal axioms, Functorial Quantum Field Theory (FQFT) axiomatizes the “Schrödinger picture”. Which is pretty cool but I don’t understand much.
One of the reasons why I though this could be the approach i want to take for non-perturbative QFT is because some times ago, i was thinking about using Lindblading dynamics (operator algebra with a BRST-cohomology modified jump operator) instead of Langevin dynamics for Stochastic quantisation, essentially treating the noise as the environment. I know this idea sounds ridiculous and it probably is, because i thought it could avoid the gribov ambiguity (a huge problem in gauge theory), but this approach you’re not trying to fight the geometry anymore so the operator algebra will just “smooth out” the topological horizon.
It’s ridiculous because I soon realised that by trying to use Lindblad you lose Lorentz invariance (you could however use a fifth fictitious time dimension to handle this just like in stochastic quantisation but it’s messy), and make renormalisation more harder. so it’s not all good. But luckily AQFT sort of fixes those problems because that’s not an idea made by a procrastinating teenager.
Now, i don’t know if my idea of Lindbladian dynamics could work or not (it’s mostly just intuition honestly) but I thought geometry to algebra is a good change of direction. Essentially I sort of rediscovered AQFT so I want to explore more into it.
I’ll be posting more about AQFT in future posts. And i’ll probably explore my open quantum system ideas more, if we could provide a rigorous prove for 0+1D Matrix Mechanics it could be a nice fool tests for the theory but that could probably take a decade because of the sheer complexity of the problem. But right now I am sort of falling behind in entrance exam preparation, so I’ll be trying to catch up while putting this on some pause. I’ll just try to pass exams and not disappoint people who have high hopes from me.

title: Research
text: My current interests lie at the mathematical foundations of quantum field theories, gauge theories and foundations of mathematics. I’m interested in a framework called Algebraic Quantum Field Theory (AQFT), which is known as a local covariant quantum theory.

title: Research
text:
Quantum Field Theory
QFTs are the theories of quantum fields on locally flat Minkowski space. It is the language in which all of physics without gravity can be described.

What is a QFT
QFT says that the universe is not made of little marble-particles flying around like your high school textbook lied to you. It’s made of fields. Invisible stretchy things that exist everywhere, all the time. Even in “empty space,” which is fake and a scam.
Each type of particle is just a tiny wiggle in its own field. Electron? Wiggle in the electron field. Photon? Wiggle in the electromagnetic field. Quark? Wiggle in a quark field that’s having a bad day. Particles aren’t objects, they’re events. Think less “tiny ball,” more “momentary glitch in the fabric of reality.”
These fields constantly jitter because quantum rules say they have to. They can’t sit still. Ever. So space itself is buzzing like a fridge at 3 a.m. You don’t hear it, but it’s judging you.
When fields interact, the wiggles influence each other. That’s what we call forces. No invisible hands pushing stuff. Just fields bumping into other fields like drunk people in a crowded kitchen. Gravity is just spacetime being bent. Electromagnetism is fields exchanging wiggles. Reality is basically group chat chaos.
QFT is the framework that lets physicists predict how these wiggles behave and interact with absurd accuracy. Like, “we measured this to twelve decimal places and it still agrees” accuracy. It’s the most successful theory humans have ever produced, which is hilarious given we still argue about how it actually works.


The mathematical Problems of QFT
Quantum Field Theory works, which is the most suspicious thing about it. mathematically, it’s a mess held together by genius, duct tape, and vibes.

First problem: the infinities. You do the maths honestly and QFT immediately spits out infinity. Not “big number,” but “lol divide by zero forever.” Infinite energy, infinite probabilities, infinite everything. Physics does not like that because infinite answers mean you did something illegal. So physicists invented renormalization, which is a polite way of saying: “Subtract the infinity, keep the useful part, and don’t think about it too hard.” And infuriatingly, it works. Predicts experiments perfectly. mathematicians still wake up angry about this.
Second problem: the theory isn’t rigorously defined. There is no fully airtight mathematical definition of an interacting quantum field in 4D spacetime. None. Zero. We use approximations, expansions, and symbolic tricks that behave well enough to get answers. QFT is more like a cookbook than a proof. Follow the recipe, don’t ask why the oven exists.
Third problem: perturbation theory is a lie we tell ourselves. Most calculations assume interactions are “small,” so we expand answers as infinite series. These series usually don’t converge. They’re asymptotic. Meaning: adding more terms eventually makes the answer worse. We stop early and pretend that’s fine. It usually is. mathematically cursed, physically accurate.
Fourth problem: path integrals are vibes-based maths. They tell you to “sum over all possible histories of the universe.” Cool. Except no one can define what that sum actually is in a strict mathematical sense. We manipulate it like it’s real because if we don’t, nothing gets calculated and everyone goes home sad.
Fifth problem: QFT breaks when gravity shows up. Try to include spacetime itself as a quantum field and the infinities come back stronger. Renormalization taps out. The maths just explodes. This is why quantum gravity is still a blood feud.



What is Constructive QFT
Instead of waving hands at infinities and pretending asymptotic series are fine, constructive QFT tries to build quantum field theories from the ground up using real mathematics. As in: define the objects, prove they exist, show they behave, no vibes, no “physicists know what we mean.”
You don’t start with particles. You start with probability measures, operator algebras, correlation functions. You prove that the theory satisfies basic sanity checks: causality, unitarity, locality. Radical ideas, apparently.
Most successes are in lower dimensions. 2D and 3D models like φ⁴, sine-Gordon, P(φ)₂. Not because we love tiny universes, but because 4D is a mathematical war crime. Still, these models are real. They exist. They obey the axioms. They’re not just formal power series cosplay.


Why this matters
Why we’re not just being pedantic:

It tells us QFT isn’t a miracle accident. Right now QFT works because it works. Constructive results prove that interacting quantum fields can exist without cheating. That the whole framework isn’t secretly inconsistent. That’s huge.
It explains why renormalization works at all. In constructive approaches, renormalization isn’t black magic. You see exactly how infinities cancel, how scales talk to each other, how the continuum limit behaves. It turns “subtract infinity lol” into controlled, explicit maths. Physicists hate this because it removes their mystique.
It separates real theories from fake ones. Not every Lagrangian defines a valid quantum theory. Constructive QFT draws a line between “formal expression” and “actual model of reality.” This is crucial if you don’t want theoretical physics to become fan fiction.
It’s essential for quantum gravity and QFT on curved space. If spacetime itself becomes dynamical, hand-wavy maths collapses instantly. You need rigor just to stand upright. Constructive methods are one of the few tools that might survive contact with quantum gravity.
It forces conceptual clarity. What is a field? What is an observable? What does “interaction” actually mean? Constructive QFT doesn’t let you dodge these questions with diagrams and vibes. It makes you answer them or go home.



Why it is hard

Infinite degrees of freedom will ruin your life. Quantum mechanics with a few particles is already weird. QFT has infinitely many interacting variables at every point in space. Every limit you take spawns new divergences. You want existence proofs? The theory immediately asks which infinity you’d like to fight first.
The continuum is hostile. You usually start on a lattice to make things sane. Discrete, finite, polite. Then you try to take the continuum limit. That limit is where everything explodes. Correlations blow up at short distances. Fields stop being functions and become distributions. Products stop existing. Welcome to Schwartz-space hell.
Interactions are singular, not small. Constructive maths loves bounds, norms, convergence. Interacting fields respond with ultraviolet catastrophes. The interaction term is not a gentle perturbation. It’s a singular object that couples behavior across all scales. This is why perturbation theory lies and nonperturbative control is so rare.
Renormalization is nonlinear and global. Renormalization isn’t just subtracting stuff. It reshapes the theory across scales. Parameters flow. Degrees of freedom rearrange themselves. Proving this flow converges, stays local, and defines a limit theory is an absolute nightmare. The renormalization group is basically chaos theory wearing a lab coat.
Positivity and unitarity are fragile. You don’t just need a measure. You need one that gives a Hilbert space with positive norm and unitary time evolution. Tiny mistakes break reflection positivity and the whole theory collapses into mathematical nonsense. Physics will still “work,” but the maths will scream.
Gauge theories are extra cursed. Constraints, redundancies, ghosts, BRST, Gribov ambiguities. You’re not even describing physical degrees of freedom directly. You’re quotienting infinite-dimensional spaces by infinite-dimensional symmetries. Proving that anything survives this process intact is… ambitious.
Four dimensions will cook you. Everything that behaves nicely in 2D or 3D turns feral in 4D. Marginal couplings. Logarithmic divergences. No small parameter. This is why we have beautiful constructive results in toy worlds and basically vibes in the real one.
You’re fighting both tribes. Physicists think you’re wasting time proving obvious things. mathematicians think you’re doing analysis while high. Funding committees think you should’ve picked machine learning. This is not a friendly ecosystem. Absolute Bonkers.



References and Futher Reading

Glimme and Jaffe, Quantum Physics: A Functional Integral Point of View.
Jaffe, Arthur (2000). Constructive Quantum Field Theory. Mathematical Physics 2000: 111-12.
Arthur Jaffe and Edward Witten, Quantum Yang-Mills.
nLabs. Constructive QFT

title: Research
text:
Mathematical Gauge Theory
Gauge theories are the modern language of mathematical thoeries of physics. A gauge theory describes fields with built-in redundancy. Not all information you write down actually matters—some of it is “fake freedom” that doesn’t change physics. The mathematics is about understanding which parts are real and how they interact.
Think of it like this:

You have a field (like the electromagnetic potential \(A_\mu\)).
You can transform it locally—change its “phase” differently at every point—and the physics (like electric and magnetic fields) doesn’t change
That’s a gauge symmetry.
The actual measurable stuff lives in the quotient space, where all configurations related by these transformations are treated as the same.

Mathematical approach:

Fiber bundles: Imagine every point in space has a little copy of a group hanging over it, like a tiny circle or matrix. The way these fibers twist and connect encodes the gauge field. Physics is captured by the geometry of the bundle.
Connections and curvature: The gauge field itself is a connection on this bundle. Curvature measures how much twisting happens when you move around a loop—this is exactly the field strength, like \(F_{\mu\nu}\) in physics.
Yang-Mills theory: A fancy, rigorous version of the gauge theory behind the strong force. mathematicians study its properties: existence of solutions, topology of the space of connections, invariants like instantons.
Topology is everything: Gauge theory isn’t just equations; it’s also about the shape of the underlying space and the bundle. Weird stuff happens, like quantization of flux or magnetic monopoles, which are really just topological constraints.


Why mathematicians love it

It bridges geometry, topology, and analysis.
It produces invariants of manifolds (like Donaldson or Seiberg-Witten invariants) that classify 4D spaces.
It formalizes ideas from physics rigorously, so you can finally stop trusting physicists’ hand-wavy arguments.

In short: mathematical gauge theory = study of fields with symmetry in the language of geometry, topology, and analysis, stripped of the physicists’ “oops let’s integrate over all paths and hope it works” approach.

Univalent Foundations
This is a somewhat different but a deep field of mathematics that i’m interested in. The ordinary mathematics used by everyone is based on set theory of Zaermelo-Frankel along with the axiom of choice, called the ZFC-system. This system is very robust to formulate almost all of ordinary mathematics (ordinary mathematics is the mathss that you do in analysis, algebra, geometry, etc instead of yapping about the foundations of mathss).
